data.text: I just keep powerbanks rather deep inside my panniers, it never occured to me to worry about their temperature too much. I worry more about food, but a simple and cheap solution is a thermo-isolated bag from any supermarket. As for the chargers, I use Anker powerbanks and an Anker charger. But again, rather for compatibility than for safety - my primary concern is the speed and effectiveness of charging (especially with all those various high-speed charging technologies).
data.author: Marcin Kysiak

data.text: Just like any other electronics, don't let them sit in direct sunlight for too long. Just keep them in your bags and they'll be fine. Chargers, no, it doesn't matter - as long as you steer clear of the cheapest no-name brands. Though if your power bank has some kind of high-speed charging - the most common now is usb C power delivery, then you might want to get a charger that can do that.
data.author: Tom Platts-Mills

data.text: USB devices are supposed to "talk" and the device needing charging is supposed to tell the charger device how much current and what voltage to use. A simple way to figure out of to look at charging specifications of the power Bank - 5, 10 and 15 W (for watts) are most common and buy a matching charger.

data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: Powerbanks getting hot during use, or during charging, is normal. Keep them out of direct sun, but if you can somewhere with airflow to cool the battery. Someone has already mentioned white powerbanks. The white shell will reflect more heat. Powerbanks getting hot when not in use is not normal. You could have a fault. This might indicate a short circuit within the powerbank, or some other fault. If the unit is in any way deformed, or swollen, immediately replace it. It could catch fire.
